occurrences.line_text: Ne other drinke there did he euer tast,
The tast of bloud of some engored beast,
To tast of ioy, and to wont pleasures to retourne.
Began some smacke of comfort new to tast,
To taste th'vntryed dint of deadly steele;
That hath thee hither brought to taste mine yre?
That of her heauenly learning he might taste,
But thou thy treasons fruit, I hope, shalt taste
After her heat the breathing cold to taste;
That he might taste the sweet consuming woe,
So did those olde Heroes hereof taste,
Therefore they mote not taste of fleshly food,
Did taste of pittie, neither gentlesse knew,
Did taste the bloud, obaying natures first beheast.
That neuer tasted grace, nor goodnesse felt,
I haue endur'd, and tasted many a bloudy wound.
Of which so soone as they once tasted had,
He euer tasted, but with penaunce sad
Which when as I, that neuer tasted blis,
When as the paine of death she tasted had,
Then famous Niobe, before she tasted
Brought aunswere backe, that ere he tasted bread,
I haue not tasted yet, yet past a boy,
Who when he once his dreadfull strokes had tasted,
For who had tasted once (as oft did he)
Ne tastest Princes pleasures, ne doest spred
And large of limbe, t'atchieue an hard emprize,
Should issue forth, t'attach that scornefull lasse.
Ne day nor night did sleepe, t'attend them on,
Being all rag'd and tatter'd, their disgraces
Their diuerse notes t'attune vnto his lay,
He gan forthwith t'auale, and way vnto me yield.
Eftsoones to court he cast t'auaunce his first degree.
And shame t'auenge so weake an enimy;
And them coniure t'auenge this shamefull iniury.
T'auenge his Pare[n]ts death on them, that had it wrought.
Whose death t'auenge, his mother mercilesse,
And cast t'auenge him of that fowle despight,
That both were bent t'auenge his vsage base,
And cast t'auenge his friends indignity.
And cast t'auenge the shame doen to his freend:
T'auenge that shame, they did on him commit;
With full intent t'auenge that villany,
And sodainely t'auenge him selfe againe,
Then as it were t'auenge his wrath on mee,
Thought sure t'auenge his grudge, & worke his foe great shame.
As time her taught, in lowly Shepheards weeds,
He taught to imitate that Lady trew,
Which being taught, he forward gan aduaunce
Taught to obay their bestiall beheasts,
For all he taught the tender ymp, was but
Walkt in that forest, whom he had not taught
What iustice euer other iudgement taught,
Where he is taught repentance, and
That she him taught celestiall discipline,
And taught him how to take assured hold
And taught the way that does to heauen bound?
Who taught his trampling steed with equall steps to tread.
Be called Ruddymane, and thereby taught,
She taught to tread, when she her selfe would grace,
For it was taught the way, which she would haue,
To him did open, as it had beene taught:
And borne of two faire Damsels, which were taught,
And first taught men a woman to obay:
And taught her first how to be conquered;
But taught the land from wearie warres to cease.
And goodly taught to tilt and turnament;
They were all taught by Triton, to obay
Taught of the Nymphe, which from her infancy
And oft young birds, which he had taught to sing
Thereto feare gaue her wings, and neede her courage taught.
And taught the carefull Mariner to play,
Taught to obay the menage of that Elfe,
And Mulla mine, whose waues I whilom taught to weep.
And all the depth of rightfull doome was taught
And all the discipline of iustice there him taught.
There she him taught to weigh both right and wrong
Thus she him trayned, and thus she him taught,
Like as the workeman had their courses taught;
Ne would be taught with any termes, to lerne
Ne none can find, but who was taught them by the Muse.
Begot of foule Echidna, as in bookes is taught.
So taught of nature, which doth litle need
Were dead, right so as Coridon had taught:
And gan t'augment her bitternesse much more:
The more t'augment her price, through praise of comlinesse.
All carelesse of his taunt and bitter rayle,
To whom that other did this taunt returne.
Not sparing him with bitter words to taunt;
With bitter taunts, and termes of vile disgrace.
His scornefull taunts vnto his teeth againe,
T'auoide the rash assault and wrathfull stowre
Fit time t'awaite auenged for to bee.
And long time hauing tand his tawney hide
Their tawney bodies, in their proudest plight:
And bit his tawny beard to shew his raging ire.
His tayle was stretched out in wondrous length,
And scaly tayle was stretcht adowne his backe full low.
His huge long tayle wound vp in hundred foldes,
With his long tayle, that horse and man to ground did rush.
His hideous tayle then hurled he about,
Whose hideous tayle his left foot did enfold,
Mighty Monoceroses, with immeasured tayles.
And all things else, the which his art did teach:
Their backward bent knees teach her humbly to obay.
To teach them truth, which worshipt her in vaine,
Iwote (quoth he) whom triall late did teach,
That none could read, except she did them teach,
Teach him the weake to strengthen, & the stro[n]g suppresse.
That first did teach the cursed steele to bight
To teach them how to vse their present state.
And our weake hands (whom need new strength shall teach)
Hard is to teach an old horse amble trew.
First rings his siluer Bell t'each sleepy wight,
Whereby his strengthes assay he might him teach.
Of senselesse words, which nature did him teach,
Hauing oft seene it tryde, as he did teach.
They teach vs, how to each degree and kynde
Most certaine markes, (sayd she) do me it teach,
Made in their friendship, as that Hag him teaches:
From thence to heauen she teacheth him the ready path.
But reason teacheth that the fruitfull seades
Need teacheth her this lesson hard and rare,
Teaching the Satyres, which her sat around,
Doing him selfe, and teaching others to doe right.
At which the bushy Teade a groome did light,
Her angrie teame breaking their bonds of peace,
Crying, O spare with guilty hands to teare
And beat their brests, and naked flesh to teare.
That causd her shed so many a bitter teare,
Oft soust in swelling Tethys saltish teare,
And from the she Beares teats her whelps to teare;
And some had wings, and some had clawes to teare,
And euery one did teare her girlond from her crowne.
And scratcht his face, and with his teeth did teare
With greedy iawes her readie for to teare;
And him assayling, sore his carkasse teare,
He wailed womanlike with many a teare,
For from her backe her garments she did teare,
But it would loose, or else a sunder teare.
Like as a curre doth felly bite and teare
And tosse the deepes, and teare the firmament,
To teare his flesh in peeces for his sin.
The Engin fiercely flying forth, doth teare
The yron charet, and the wheeles did teare,
Of Bacchus Priests her owne deare flesh did teare.
To rend and teare, what so she can oppresse;
Then would she inly fret, and grieue, and teare
And from her head her lockes he nigh did teare,
For he regarded neither playnt nor teare,
Gan teare her hayre, and all her garments rent,
So did these two this Knight oft tug and teare.
Gan him to hale, and teare, and scratch, and bite;
The which amongst them they in peeces teare,
And snatch, and byte, and rend, and tug, and teare;
And his owne flesh he readie was to teare:
With many a ioyfull kisse, and many a melting teare.
Nought sparing them, the more did tosse and teare,
My Fathers kingdome,--There she stopt with teares;
Let me not dye in languor and long teares.
Melting in teares, then gan she thus lament;
That my fraile eyes these lines with teares do steepe,
And drizling teares did shed for pure affection.
Redounding teares did choke th'end of her plaint,
Her tender brest in bitter teares all night,
And all the way she wets with flowing teares:
Doth weepe full sore, and sheddeth tender teares:
Tho when her well of teares she wasted had,
And all the while salt teares bedeawd the hearers cheaks.
And her faire face with teares was fowly blubbered.
From teares abstaine, for griefe his hart did grate,
So shedding many teares, they closd the earth againe.
In that knights heart, and wordes with bitter teares did steepe.
Welling out streames of teares, and quite dismayd
That cheekes with teares, and sides with bloud did all abound.
Of all my sorrow, and of these sad teares,
They crownd the second Constantine with ioyous teares,
He daintie couch with teares, which closely she did weepe.
That the hard rocks could scarse from teares refraine,
In stead of rest thou lendest rayling teares,
Few trickling teares she softly forth let fall,
Wiping the teares from her suffused eyes,
With herbs, with charms, with cou[n]sell, & with teares,
Asswage the fury, which his entrails teares:
And blubbred face with teares of her faire eyes:
While teares stood in his eies, few drops of bitternesse.
With womanish teares, and with vnwarlike smarts,
That I with teares full oft doe pittie it,
Her selfe she threw, and teares gan shed amaine;
Amongst her teares immixing prayers meeke,
And teares it all with terrible mischance.
And eft gan into tender teares to melt.
Moued with pity of her plenteous teares.
Then running water, tempred with his teares,
With that he forth would poure so plenteous teares,
Then after many teares and sorrowes spent,
Sometime with tender teares to let her goe,
Is hardned more with my aboundant teares.
With many bitter teares shed from his blubbred eyne.
Bursting forth teares, like springs out of a banke,
And lastly Griefe did plead, and many teares forth powre.
With humble prayers and intreatfull teares;
And bursting forth in teares; Ah my sweet boyes,
With heauie eyne, from teares vneath refrayning,
And with her teares his wounds did wash and steepe.
Which she perceiuing, did with plenteous teares
From his soft eyes the teares he wypt away,
For which I thus doe mourne, and poure forth ceaselesse teares.
But shedding few soft teares from tender eyne,
Yet were her words but wynd, & all her teares but water.
Wasting her goodly hew in heauie teares,
Then bursting forth in teares, which gushed fast
I put the teares of my contrition,
Ne cared she her wound in teares to steepe,
And gushing forth in teares, was so opprest,
Bedeaw'd with teares there left it in the place:
In milder tearmes, as list them to deuise:
With better tearmes she did him entertaine;
But tears, nor charms, nor herbs, nor counsell might
Mongst ioyes mixing some tears, mongst wele, some wo,
And from the she Beares teats her whelps to teare;
In his strong hand their rugged teats to hold,
And asked, to what end they clomb that tedious height.
High heauen behold the tedious toyle, ye for me take.
Of Britomart after long tedious toyle,
My tedious trauell doe forget thereby;
To passe the tedious trauell of the way;
Yet harnessed his firie-footed teeme,
Which with a teeme of scaly Phocas bound
Vnfitly yokt together in one teeme,
But here my wearie teeme nigh ouer spent
That bare-head knight for dread and dolefull teene,
Gainst that proud Paynim king, that workes her teene:
Either for grieuous shame, or for great teene,
To cloke her guile with sorrow and sad teene;
Nor fry in hartlesse griefe and dolefull teene.
Religious reuerence doth buriall teene,
Of gods high prayse, and of their loues sweet teene,
With other signes of sorrow and impatient teene.
And put away remembrance of late teene;
Like as a Snake, whom wearie winters teene,
He forced was to strike, and saue him selfe from teene.
The secret cause and nature of his teene,
In their first flowre, before this fatall teene
Betweene his cankred teeth a venemous tode,
Still as he rode, he gnasht his teeth, to see
Chattring their yron teeth, and staring wide
His monstrous scalpe downe to his teeth it tore,
Her teeth out of her rotten gummes were feld,
Three ranckes of yron teeth enraunged were,
Yet his great yron teeth he still did grind,
His grated teeth for great disdeigne, and shooke
And both did gnash their teeth, & both did threaten life.
Thereat the feend his gnashing teeth did grate,
Another in her teeth did gnaw a rush:
He tombling downe, with gnashing teeth did bite
And scratcht his face, and with his teeth did teare
With huge great teeth, like to a tusked Bore:
And gnashed with his teeth, as if he band
Her heart for rage did grate, and teeth did grin:
And laught so loud, that all his teeth wide bare
And gnasht his teeth, and his head at him shooke,
Was wan and leane, that all her teeth arew,
His scornefull taunts vnto his teeth againe,
Gnashing his cruell teeth at him in vaine,
Least that the beasts sharpe teeth had any wound
Gnashing his grinded teeth with griesly looke,
For that beastes teeth, which wounded you tofore,
And with his teeth and nailes, in present vew,
And downe him plucking, with his nayles and teeth
All set with yron teeth in raunges twaine,
Or bit them with his banefull teeth of iniury.
And burnt his beastly hart t'efforce her chastitye.
He gan t'efforce the euidence anew,
Sir Calidore vpcheard, and to her teld
Tydings of warre and worldly trouble tell?
Of a straunge man I can you tidings tell,
Came to their wicked maister, and gan tell
And oft would flie away. O who can tell
And tell, both who ye be, and who that tooke your part.
Then his dull eares, to heare what she did tell;
And fortunes tell, and read in louing bookes,
To tell the sad sight, which mine eies haue red:
But for to tell her lamentable cace,
And with them all departes, to tell his great distresse.
Tell on (quoth she) the wofull Tragedie,
Thy sad tongue cannot tell more heauy plight,
Then heare the storie sad, which I shall tell you briefe.
Who answerd him full soft, he could not tell.
He could not tell: ne euer other answere made.
He could not tell, againe he answered.
His answere likewise was, he could not tell.
That straunger knight his name and nation tell;
That I may tell this haplesse history?
Or anguish in her hart, is hard to tell:
Could hardly him intreat, to tell his griefe:
Cannot describe, nor wit of man can tell;
But his most hideous head my toung to tell
To tell, how he had seene the Dragons fatall fall.
How can I tell, but that his talants may
What needs me tell their feast and goodly guize,
To tell that dawning day is drawing neare,
To tell, were as to striue against the streame.
And bad tell on the tenor of his plaint;
To tell this ruefull tale; thy sight could win thee grace.
Toung hates to tell the rest, that eye to see abhord.
And tell the cause of your conceiued paine.
In which he hath great glorie wonne, as I heare tell.
Certes (said he) well mote I shame to tell
And tell the secret of your mortall smart;
Tell then, ï¿½ Lady tell, what fatall priefe
Tell then, ï¿½ Lady tell, what fatall priefe
My tongue can tell, so farre all sense they pas:
That they his mothers innocence may tell,
He is conuaide, but how or where, here fits not tell.
To tell from whence he came through ieopardie,
Tell on, faire Sir, said she, that dolefull tale,
If thou didst, tell me, that I may her ouertake.
For who can tell (and sure I feare it ill)
Fled fast away, to tell his funerall
Long were to tell the troublous stormes, that tosse
Ne toung did tell, ne hand these handled not,
O who can tell the prayses of that makers might!
Ne can I tell, ne can I stay to tell
Ne can I tell, ne can I stay to tell
Let Scaldis tell, and let tell Hania,
Let Scaldis tell, and let tell Hania,
And let the marsh of Estham bruges tell,
But for to tell the sumptuous aray
In plainer wise to tell her grieuaunce she begonne.
Thy selfe thy prayses tell, and make them knowen farre.
Tell me some markes, by which he may appeare,
Shall me debarre, tell me therefore my liefest liefe.
To weet, the learned Merlin, well could tell,
He bad tell on; and then she thus began.
And to her said, Beldame, by that ye tell,
Doth by her blushing tell, that she did lye
Behold the man, and tell me Britomart,
Bards tell of many women valorous
Her deare sonnes destinie to her to tell,
To tell the same. I lately did depart
Which way she fared hath, good Sir tell out of hand.
And tell me, if that ye my sonne haue heard,
And their true loues without suspition tell abrode.
And tell the idle tidings to his Dame:
As for my name, it mistreth not to tell;
Ah gentle Squire (quoth he) tell at one word,
In deed Sir knight (said he) one word may tell
To tell what tydings of faire Florimell became.
And so her selfe did alwaies to him tell;
And said, his boat the way could wisely tell:
To tell of Satyrane, where I him left of late.
Which now in Faerie court all men do tell,
That ye doe tell in such vncertaintee?
Into that Castle (as that Squire does tell.)
Vnto those knights aduenturous, to tell
Whenas the noble Britomart heard tell
Who had forgot, that whilome I heard tell
And tell thy griefe, if any hidden lye;
Ne word he had to speake, his griefe to tell,
He whispered in her eare, and did her tell,
Long were to tell each other louely fit,
Long were to tell the amorous assayes,
In wauering wemens wit, that none can tell,
Yet should it be a pleasant tale, to tell
Or to them tydings tell, that mote their harts delight.
That whether were more false, full hard it is to tell.
I saw, why should I doubt to tell the same?
Then tell (quoth Blandamour) and feare no blame,
Tell what thou saw'st, maulgre who so it heares.
And she so farre astray, as none can tell.
Her cause of comming she to tell began.
Or how their liues were eekt, she did not tell;
And drawne it was (that wonder is to tell)
The which by course befals me here to tell:
And not for vertuous vse, which some doe tell
To tell the feature of each goodly face.
The hard aduentures and strange haps to tell;
Were long to tell; therefore I here will stay
So doest thou now to her, of whom I tell,
To tell (quoth she) that which ye see, needs not;
Seeking aduentures, where he mote heare tell;
And tell the course of his captiuitie;
To tell through what misfortune he had far'd,
Comprised be, I will them in another tell.
Scudamour doth his conquest tell,
Long were to tell the trauell and long toile,
All which not if an hundred tongues to tell,
Helpe me to tell the names of all those floods,
That whilome were (as antique fathers tell)
Cannot recount, nor tell their hidden race,
With many more, whose names no tongue can tell.
To tell the sands, or count the starres on hye,
For much more eath to tell the starres on hy,
Whose names and nations were too long to tell,
I will them tell though vnto no man neare:
And such was he, of whom I haue to tell,
Your owne dead Ladies head, to tell abrode your shame.
And gan of sundry newes his store to tell,
To tell the glorie of the feast that day,
And turn'd aside for shame to heare, what he did tell.
For proofe shew forth thy sword, and let it tell,
And their young bloodie babe to him gan tell;
Now tell me Amidas, if that ye may,
And sent them home to tell a piteous tale,
But tell, Sir Terpin, ne let you amate
Tell, that to morrow I with him will fight,
Tho gan she tell her all, that she had donne,
And tell what euer it be, good or bad,
Forcing in vaine the rest to her to tell,
For which the earth (as they the story tell)
And tell him for his sake thy life thou gauest.
A dreadfull depth, how deepe no man can tell;
First gan he tell, how this that seem'd so faire
Which when the Prince heard tell, his heart gan earne
And bitter curses, horrible to tell,
To passe them ouer, where them list to tell:
And tell him that not for such slaughters sake
Now tell, if please you, of the good successe,
And for what cause, tell if thou haue it knowne.
But should it not displease thee it to tell;
To tell, what cruell hand hath thus arayd
And tell withall, the lamentable plight,
Much was he then encombred, ne could tell
To whom she thus, What need me Sir to tell,
As ye may know, when time shall be to tell the same.
Tell me what worlds despight, or heauens yre
I must a while forbeare to you to tell;
But tell me Lady, wherefore doe you beare
But first it falleth me by course to tell
And them to tell him courteously besought,
Yet was not so, but as old stories tell
Whose sundry parts were here too long to tell:
Tell me, what mote these dainty Damzels be,
Tell, me what were they all, whose lacke thee grieues so sore.
But for to tell the dolefull dreriment,
Hath wrought this wicked deed: doe feare away, and tell.
Whose heauy tydings now I haue to tell.
But first, ere I doe his aduentures tell,
To tell her, how the heauens had her graste,
There leaue we them in ioy, and let vs tell
That endlesse were to tell. The Elfin Knight,
To see the hatefull sunne, that he might tell
If that of such a Ladie she could tellen ought.
Then wonne from death, she bad him tellen plaine
But he him forst to stay, and tellen free
Whylome as antique stories tellen vs,
But the sage wisard telles, as he has red,
Of death and dolour telling sad tidings;
She would it eeke, and make much worse by telling,
His loues and lignage Arthur tells
Th'amazed vulgar tels of warres and mortall fight.
But what art thou, that telst of Nephews kilt?
Who glad t'embosome his affection vile,
For loth he was his noble hands t'embrew
Those mighty palmes, the which ye wont t'embrew
His seuenfold teme behind the stedfast starre,
With which he forward lasht the laesie teme,
Her twyfold Teme, of which two blacke as pitch,
And them constraine in equall teme to draw.
As he his toylesome teme that way did guyde,
A teme of Dolphins raunged in aray,
Her teme at her commaundement quiet stands,
And lose the teme out of his weary waine,
But now my teme begins to faint and fayle,
As the bright sunne, what time his fierie teme
Now turne againe my teme thou iolly swayne,
And let their temed fishes softly swim
Which foure great Hippodames did draw in temewise tyde.
Or the Thessalian Tempe, where of yore
Meet for her temper and complexion:
Temper his griefe, and turned it to cheare,
And calmd his wrath with goodly temperance.
Through goodly handling and wise temperance.
But temperance (said he) with golden squire
He would through temperance and stedfastnesse,
But all your hurts may soone through te[m]perance be easd.
The house of Temperance, in which
Now gins this goodly frame of Temperance
Through goodly temperance, and affection chaste,
Sith now of dayes such temperance is rare
Sate goodly Temperance in garments clene,
His countenaunce demure and temperate,
With temperate aduice discounselled,
Who euer doth to temperaunce apply
The enimies of Temperaunce
But wisedomes powre, and temperaunces might,
Through tempering of her words & lookes by wondrous skill.
That promist ayde the tempest to withstand:
Which therein shrouded from the tempest dred,
And calme the tempest of his passion wood;
As when a windy tempest bloweth hye,
Them from the tempest of his wrathfulnesse,
That craue but rowme to rest, while tempest ouerblo'th.
As glad of that small rest, as Bird of tempest gon.
Another knight, whom tempest thither brought,
To calme the tempest of his troubled thought:
Till time the tempest doe thereof delay
Like as a ship, whom cruell tempest driues
An hideous tempest seemed from below,
